textDisplay: The back looks like it could've been a BMW, the front look sort of like a Ford crossed with a Mitsubishi Lancer

I think this video makes a fundamental mistake. We must be careful in how we measure performance as to not be biased.
8:40 You say that it's impossible for a machine to make a human error -- well of course, this is by definition that only a human can make a human error.
10:05 You say it can detect a stop sign or pedestrian 500 meters away -- this is a biased way of measuring performance because it's a strict comparison of detection mechanisms (eyes vs. cameras/radar).

I can say AI driven cars would solve many problems like drunk driving, elderly drivers who probably shouldn't drive but have to, and I think in time it can help greatly with traffic congestion. But let's not overlook the problems it creates: expense of ownership, general reliability, 'software' or 'programming errors' can result in any kind of response (compared to humans which almost universally respond to driving issues w/ braking), AI might just as well do the opposite, hence I'd expect fatalities to be less frequent, but involve more people when they occur.

I can't help but recall my office mate in my PhD program who took his Ford truck to the dealership when his A/C stopped working. They told him it needed a software update. I do not want the machine I drive to work to be capable of failure due to a software update. My truck has an ECU for the fuel injection, but that's it and that's enough. I installed my own infotainment center running Android on a touchscreen, but the car itself is dumb as rocks.... 14 years and counting I've only had one (1) 50K mile scheduled maintenance, oil changes, 1 set of new tires, and 3 lead acid battery changes, and 3 or 4 new windshield wipers installed... You won't beat that with a 'smart car' in terms of cost of ownership and the industry knows it.

I'll be frank, I am on board with replacing human drivers as soon as possible and this video was a ding to my confidence in that future. We cannot move forward with this technology if "ignore the edge cases, those are rare" is the mindset of the people in charge of it. I sincerely hope that is you injecting your viewpoint onto it and that's not coming from Waymo.

The clip you showed of someone arguing an edge case where it encourages people not to wear helmets is not invalidated by its rareness. People don't act based on statistics. If they did, we wouldn't be in the mess we're in right now in 2021. We don't need to stop pushing autonomous vehicles forward for this helmet question (the system is nowhere near capable enough of accurately identifying safety equipment and making decisions based on it so it's not a relevant question) but other questions DO need to be addressed.

Let me give you a perspective that is a bit more worrying to me. Twice in the past few months we've seen a huge swath of the internet go offline for a few hours when a major cloud host went down. First Google, then Amazon. It's been a wakeup call to some that we've overcentralized our online infrastructure, but others are ignoring it...because of course they are. Just last week we had a zero day where all Apache servers (the most common web server software). The concern with automated driving is it potentially creates a very deadly single point of failure. I don't see that happening with Waymo's current fleet as they are largely autonomous and, importantly, nowhere near the most common vehicle on the road. But let's fast forward to when an automated system controlling vehicles is as common as Toyota vehicles. There are three major issues that need to be clearly addressed before many of us will trust allowing them to grow towards that point.
1. Does it stop working if some external service goes offline - GPS, internet, a server in Toyota's basement, whatever. Obviously, given a certain country it's being developed in, it can currently stand to be without internet for a while because American internet, but we can't get ourselves dependent on a transportation technology that stops functioning entirely if an online service goes down. A smartbulb that won't work anymore because the server discontinued is a small inconvenience, but if Ford goes under and shuts off servers their vehicles depend on, that can result in a lot of slow and painful deaths. 
2. Can the fleet be compromised. The talk of cars that communicate with each other sounds great...unless you work in computing. Then it sounds like someone forgot bad people exist. That sort of inter-connectivity is like handing the nuclear codes to anyone who figures out or is told how to send commands to those cars. If someone figured out how to send the command to accelerate over that communications system (which, even if the communications system doesn't convey commands is still possible) then millions could die within hours.
3. Can individual cars be attacked. For a while, many banks and credit card companies were putting wireless chips in cards and insisting it was "safe". Security experts demonstrated a small loop of wire that could fit in someone's pocket, along with a small control device could pull all the needed information off the cards from a distance and reproduce it on demand. Now those chips aren't in most cards anymore. A few manufacturers are desperately claiming theirs are "safe" but few are gullible enough to believe them now. This one is going to have to be demonstrated, not merely assured. Something like letting a few hacker conventions have at the vehicle on a closed course where they won't have any qualms about making it do things that would otherwise be lethal. This one is more for avoiding unnecessary roadblocks. We don't want car manufacturers to get gunshy about automated software like banks did with the card chips. Yes, you can get people to quickly trust the car to drive, but it can just as quickly generate distrust and outrage if one person gets killed because a malicious individual tricked the vehicle into doing something wrong. You would also need to test against large scale shutdown attacks such as saturating an area with the right frequency of light that the LIDAR is using or painting something with a material that scatters or absorbs that light.

Saving lives is a good goal, but if you leave the door open to losing more lives, or if you rush forward so fast that you stumble and slow down the process, then you've done a disservice. Being better than what we have now isn't good enough. We have to work through the ramifications of it to avoid unintended consequences.

Many years ago, people worked out that putting lead in gasoline would solve a major problem. And an entire generation got lead poisoning from that. Unintended consequences can be disastrous beyond your wildest dreams, especially for something as ubiquitous as transportation. We need this technology to succeed, not be held back by early failures that could have been anticipated if we had listened to the people we thought were just naysayers.

A driverless car would be ideal for my visually impaired girlfriend as it would solve her problem of short distance to medium distance travel. A lot of her time is wasted going to the start point of public transport, switching public transport and from end point to final destination. However, this technology is only viable if it's truly autonomous 100% of the time. That means not only must it be able to navigate all kinds of obstacles like roadworks and accidents, but also all kinds of weather. (Rain still seems to be a problem for Waymo sensory systems.) A lot of road infrastructure has to be either changed or augmented to accommodate these vehicles. For example traffic regulatory systems (traffic lights, speed signs, etc) need some way of communicating with the vehicle as well as communication between vehicles. Also for better or worse a lot of legislation has to be done. (It took literally centuries to come up with road rules.) And we as a society have to accept that small and major accidents will happen. I also imagine that "car ownership" is going to be an issue. It looks that Tesla bets that cars will be still owned by the majority of individuals, while the rest (Alphabet, Ford, etc) assumes that a "car as a service" is the more likely outcome. I can imagine that we might not even have individual cars in the future, but something that is a hybrid between car, bus and train.
So from an engineering point of view I understand your enthusiasm. In the end it's not the engineering but timing and luck which determines the success of autonomous vehicles.

Not even close to autonomy. Everything but Tesla is miles away. Waymo is crap. Gm and Ford are crap. Tesla is billions of miles ahead of the competition. Which means you’re many times more likely to die in these crappy off brand “autonomous” cars

He didn't mention the make of most of the vehicles in the footage. The clip was simply an example, and not disparaging anything in particular. Many viewers won't even know or care that such and such clip is of a different manufacturer's vehicle in an accident, and it doesn't matter. If you're talking about the importance of seat belts on behalf of Subaru, for example, who cares if the stock footage of the dummy's head crashing into the steering column is from inside a Ford?

1. Many people including me en joy driving - do you want to force what we consider a reduced quality of life on us ?
2. Humans can navigate to any location. How do you get an autonomous vehicle to be able to navigate to loacations and/or along paths not correctly stored in a database ?
3. Humans can decide to ignore rules in an emergency - machines cannot decide to ignore rules. Eg. here in Denmark any car can be turned into an emergency ambulance and can violate speed limits etc. at the responsibility of the driver.
4. I like my privacy - I know its hard enough allready to get a car that wont record where the car is at what time, how fast it is driving etc. now because off all those stupid gadgets people seem to crave, but how can I trust the maker of an autonomous car to respect my privacy any more than all the other makers of devices for the "internet of things" that so far are happy to spy on us to give us a better customer experience.
5. Hacking Similar to 4. Any device capabable of communicating can be hacked and corrupted - eg. someone might make all Ford cars in NYC refuse to move - imagine the chaos. or eg. Imagine someone ordering your car to go to a location different than the one you intended to go to and locks the car.

I just dont like sorrounding myself with all sorts of automated gadgets doing things I can trivially do myself - I dont want to be like the fat people in floating chairs in the Wall-E movie. Do you ?
I d rather drive I'm ! not ditching the idea of a 2011 ford ranger

They can only go on roads that have been meticulously mapped, in perfect weather, under constant monitoring by a remote operator. 

These demos they do are carefully planned out and highly controlled. They are designed to give investors FOMO and convince them to invest in companies that are not currently and may never be profitable. I saw one demo Ford did where the had a driver disguised as the front seat.

As always, Derek a great video.  However, is this an important problem (glorified taxi service) to solve first?  How about starting with Lane Keeping for all trucks on Interstates/Freeways?  Regarding the commute to work and back, has the Covid Pandemic not shown that working (any one for a zoom?) from home for many businesses can eliminate much of the commute issue.  A follow up video suggestion: Impact of successful Waymo like systems:  Gone is the ICE because Waymo will want a 1 to 2 million mile power plant.  Auto industry collapse, now what do Toyota, Ford or Mercedes do?
I knew a guy that was an engineer for this. He drove a Ford truck so they made him park in the farthest lot.

We're still years and years away from full level 5 autonomy, IF it's even possible to ever achieve. Despite what the auto industry has been saying, it's really not that easy to create an automated system that can deal with every single weird thing we come across on the road.

And even IF they get it there, it'll take an outlawing of non-autonomous vehicles before I ever trust my life to software designed by GM / Ford etc's lowest bidder.

@@mollygrahamguelph Transparency would ideally be the answer, it's just a pity that even trusted companies like Ford, (and i'm a mustang owner), and it's exploding fuel tanks that cost more than human lives to recall. The fact is that with more complexity, especially with intellectual property/patents/right to repair in the mix [not that that's a bad thing], it is easier to hide design flaws and omissions when all that is cared about is the bottom line. We don't need the capitalist mess, we can already survive as a species without it, the real question is: will those at the financial top ever be satisfied with equal...... (Sorry for the diatribe).........................

The future predicted in CPG Grey's "Humans need not apply" is coming. That terrifying concern aside...

Surprisingly, I don't have all that much issue with driverless cars. I mostly look forward to it.

My concerns start with driving being effectively a subscription service (maybe one ride at a time), rather than private ownership. Do we expect that this will get down to Tesla, Toyota, or Ford where you can own and maintain your car? 

Also, this is probably the sci-fi nerd in me talking, but will this be something where mega-corporations will control (and more overtly track) our every movement? I doubt Google will make this data open source to create competition, so anyone else will need a similar sizeable outlay of funds to compete, so only similar established corporations will likely have the funds for projects like this with years of no return on investment. Google makes money by knowing everything I do. Will they do that even more with this?

In March,  I got into an accident and had to buy a new car.  My new car?  A 2019 Ford Fusion Titanium with lane assist. I used this feature in the rental I had just before I bought the car.  It was a key feature when buying the new car as well.  Why?  Heavy rain one day on the highway limited my visibility to under 30 feet.  When I couldn't see the tail lights of the cars in front of me,  adaptive cruise control could still see the car ahead of me,  keeping my distance in check.  When I couldn't see the lane markers beside me,  lane assist kept me between the lines.  The reality is,  these complex systems are super useful and aid us quicker than we can react ourselves.  The takeaway is that these features likely saved me from getting into another accident,  thus likely saved a life.  Fully autonomous vehicles,  when and if designed correctly,  I feel,  can greatly improve safety in the road.

I would prefer we just make more public transport and build on that technology. A world in which roads are 'efficiently filled with cars' sounds like an anti-pedestrian hell scape. Honestly yeah it's never been the autonomous cars that I don't trust, it's 100% the humans all around the car that are being stupid or think they own the road. :( If this level of autonomous car were affordable I would be all for this being the norm, and then driving cars being treated as novelties and cruisers like an old VW bus or a Ford Model T.

What will be the fun when u cannot drive ur own freshly bought hellcat ...not race Ferraris not jump a Ford raptor or drift a supra .... This is good idea  for disabled people but is useless for fun or thrill purposes

Driverless cars might be a future but its not gonna be common for quite a while. Average age of cars in my country is about 10 years old and trending up. The halt in this technology at the first serious accident, and then again at the first death due to this technology, will be significant. 

The push back from police departments as it will lessen revenue raising, the security risk (personal and national) of having widespread automation, political special interest groups aswell.

Personally, even if statistically safer I do not wish to trust fully in the car industry which continually fails on grounds of safety.  
Think about airbags, development started in the 1950s, modern design reached in the mid 60s yet over 100 million vehicles had to recalled over the explosive takata airbags.
Or first seatbelt patent in 1885, yet GM had to recall 2020 models because they could light the car on fire or the recent ford recall for them not activating in a crash.

And alot of people just like driving.
